Problem:
Consider a linear integral transformation given by \\(I[f(t)] = \\int_{0}^{\\infty} K(t, s) f(s) ds\\), where \\(K(t, s)\\) is a kernel function. We investigate the impact of a control function \\( h(s) \\) added to the input function \\( f(s) \\), resulting in a modified input \\( f(s) + h(s) \\).

Given \\( I[f(t)] \\) at some time t, can we specifically determine what control function \\( h(s) \\) was applied, assuming the initial function \\( f(s) \\) is known?
Explanation: Even with known \\( f(s) \\), the specific form of \\( h(s) \\) cannot be uniquely determined from \\( I[f(t)] \\) alone, owing to potential overlaps in the effects of different control functions due to the inherent nature of integral transformations and kernel variability.

causal_map_integration: The application of the control function h(s) to the input function f(s) affects the output of the integral transformation I[f(t)]. Knowing I[f(t)] and f(s) does not uniquely determine h(s) because the integral transformation also depends on f(s).
